item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: arraybolt3
item.description:
If I can get work time allocated to this, I’ll work on it. As a short-term solution, you can run something like this while booted into PERSISTENT Mode | SYSMAINT Session | system maintenance tasks:

cat <<EOF | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/set-apple-kb-backlight.service
[Unit]
Description=Enable keyboard backlight on Apple systems

[Service]
Type=oneshot
RemainAfterExit=yes
ExecStart=bash -c -- 'echo 255 > /sys/class/leds/smc::kbd_backlight/brightness'

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target sysmaint-boot.target
EOF
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable set-apple-kb-backlight.service
sudo systemctl start set-apple-kb-backlight.service

This should make the backlight immediately turn on, and it should be automatically turned on each time you boot up thereafter. If max brightness is too intense, change the 255 in echo 255 to a smaller value. (This will create a new file at /etc/systemd/system/set-apple-kb-backlight.service, so if you need to change things later, that’s the file to change.)

(The ideal solution would be for Kicksecure’s backlight-tool to display the keyboard backlight as an additional device with controllable brightness, but that will take a lot longer to make happen.)

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: arraybolt3
item.description:
This might be a tricky one. Apple keyboard backlights are apparently controlled by a sysfs file, which likely requires administrator permissions to modify. Existing tools might not work with user-sysmaint-split installed unless they install a privileged background process that actually does the job of changing the backlight brightness. If you remove user-sysmaint-split though, you might be able to use something like brightnessctl to adjust the keyboard backlight.

I unfortunately do not have an Intel-based Macbook to test with, so I can’t really create a tool for adjusting this that integrates with Kicksecure. (I made a tool for adjusting the display backlight, which is part of Kicksecure 18; a similar tool would probably work for the keyboard backlight, but would require someone with compatible hardware to create the tool or add support for keyboard backlight changing to the existing tool.)
